Those who were arrogant will say, "Indeed, we are all [together] in the Fire. Indeed, Allah has judged between the servants." (al-Mu'min/40: 47-48)
text.29:
Then Allah explains the rejection of their leaders regarding the accusation. The leaders stated that they did not mislead those people. It was the followers themselves who, due to their nature, became disbelievers and committed acts of shirk and disobedience. They associated partners with Allah through idols and statues and committed various sins that caused their hearts to be sealed, so they no longer knew the right and good path.

Furthermore, the leaders refuted that they had power over their followers, misleading them and causing them to disbelieve, and that they never prevented them from determining their choices, which actions were bad and which actions were good. But it was the inclination of the followers themselves that caused them to commit disbelief and disobedience.
text.30:
Then Allah explains the rejection of their leaders regarding the accusation. The leaders stated that they did not mislead those people. It was the followers themselves who, due to their nature, became disbelievers and committed acts of shirk and disobedience. They associated partners with Allah through idols and statues and committed various sins that caused their hearts to be sealed, so they no longer knew the right and good path.

Furthermore, the leaders refuted that they had power over their followers, misleading them and causing them to disbelieve, and that they never prevented them from choosing between bad and good deeds. But it was the inclination of the followers themselves that caused them to commit disbelief and disobedience.
text.31:
On the Day of Judgment, the idol worshippers will acknowledge that they were excessive in the past due to their own inherent nature and disposition, which inclined them towards disbelief and evil. Therefore, it is fitting that on the Day of Judgment they receive punishment from Allah.

Good or bad recompense for an action is a natural consequence, because the action was performed with full awareness. Therefore, each person need not blame others, except themselves. It is not appropriate for one group to blame another. Each should receive the recompense for their actions. Those who are obedient to Allah and His Messenger will receive rewards in this world and the hereafter, and those who are astray will enter hell. Such is the promise of the Lord conveyed to mankind through His messengers. The idol worshippers, friends of Satan, knew this promise of the Lord, yet they turned away from goodness and obedience.

The leaders of that time will declare that they were the ones who led their followers astray. They did so because of their desire for the followers to follow in their footsteps. However, in reality, it was the inherent nature and efforts of the followers themselves that caused them to commit disbelief and disobedience, thus suffering the torment as previously warned by the messengers.
text.32:
On the Day of Judgment, the idol worshippers will confess that they had previously transgressed due to their own inherent nature and disposition, which inclined them towards disbelief and evil. Therefore, it is fitting that on the Day of Judgment they receive punishment from Allah.

Reward or punishment for an action is a natural consequence, because the action was performed with full awareness. Therefore, each person need not blame others, except themselves. It is not appropriate for one group to blame another. Each should receive the recompense for their actions. Those who are obedient to Allah and His Messenger will receive rewards in this world and the Hereafter, and those who are astray will enter Hell. Such is the promise of the Lord conveyed to mankind through His messengers. The idol worshippers, the friends of Satan, knew of God's promise, yet they turned away from goodness and obedience.

The leaders of that time will declare that they were the ones who led their followers astray. They did so because of their desire for their followers to follow in their footsteps. However, in truth, it was the nature and efforts of the followers themselves that caused them to commit disbelief and disobedience, thus suffering the torment as previously warned by the messengers.
text.33:
In this verse, Allah affirms that punishment is inflicted upon the leaders and their followers. Both groups accuse each other and pass the blame, but they are both in error. Those who mislead will certainly receive a heavier punishment. They not only bear their own burdens, but also must bear the burdens of those whom they misled.

The punishment that God inflicts upon the polytheists is in accordance with God's justice towards His servants. Everyone who sins will receive punishment according to their crime. Likewise, those who do good will be rewarded according to their good deeds.
text.34:
In this verse, Allah affirms that punishment is inflicted upon the leaders and their followers. Both groups accuse each other and pass the responsibility, but they are both in error. Those who mislead will certainly receive a heavier punishment. They not only bear their own burdens, but also must bear the burdens of those whom they misled.

The punishment that God inflicts upon the polytheists is in accordance with God's justice towards His servants. Everyone who sins will receive punishment according to their crime. Likewise, those who do good will be rewarded according to their good deeds.
text.35:
Then Allah elaborates on some of the reasons for the punishment inflicted upon the sinners. When they were in the world, they rejected the teachings of *tauhid* when it was conveyed to them and turned away, unwilling to listen to the recitation of the *kalimat tauhid* "La ilaha illallah," which means, "There is no god worthy of worship except Allah." The reason for their rejection was their perceived impossibility of abandoning the deities of their ancestors.

They inherited the tradition of worshipping idols and statues from generation to generation. According to them, this was a truth that must be continuously upheld. They would not abandon that belief simply to listen to the words of a mad poet whose speech was not worthy of being listened to and whose teachings were not worth hearing. According to them, the Prophet's words were full of fantasy.

The statement of the disbelievers, spoken before the Prophet during his life in the world with arrogance, shows that they denied the Oneness of Allah and denied the prophethood of Muhammad, peace be upon him (saw). The first denial was the arrogant refusal to listen to the teachings of *tauhid*, and the second denial was the statement of the impossibility of abandoning those deities to obey the Messenger whom they accused of being mad.
text.36:
Then Allah elaborates on some of the reasons for the punishment inflicted upon the sinners. While in the world, they rejected the teachings of *tauhid* when presented to them and turned away, unwilling to listen to the recitation of the *kalimat tauhid* "La ilaha illallah," which means, "There is no god worthy of worship except Allah." The reason for their rejection was their perceived impossibility of abandoning the deities of their ancestors.

They inherited the tradition of worshipping idols and statues from generation to generation. According to them, this was a truth that must be continuously upheld. They would not abandon that belief simply to listen to the words of a mad poet whose speech was unworthy of being listened to and whose teachings were unnecessary to hear. According to them, the Prophet's words were full of fantasy.

The statement of the disbelievers, uttered before the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) while he was alive in the world with full arrogance, shows that they denied the oneness of Allah and denied the prophethood of Muhammad (saw). The first denial was the arrogant refusal to listen to the teachings of *tauhid*, and the second denial was the statement of the impossibility of abandoning those deities to obey the Messenger whom they accused of being mad.
text.37:
In this verse, Allah refutes the accusations of the disbelievers of Mecca. Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) never uttered imaginary words as a poet, but in reality, he was a bringer and supporter of the truth. The teachings of *tauhid* (monotheism) that he propagated need no further doubt, because the oneness of God is confirmed by sound reasoning and can be proven with concrete evidence. It is not fitting to call the Messenger a poet when he brings the true teachings. The same teachings were also brought previously by the prophets of old.

The teachings of *tauhid* that he brought continue the teachings of *tauhid* brought by the previous prophets, and are by no means the creation of Muhammad (peace be upon him). So the accusations against the Messenger as a poet and a madman are only due to hatred and denial. Allah will surely inflict a painful torment and a severe punishment on the disbelievers who accuse the Messenger with that vile accusation. The punishment for those who deny the teachings of the messengers can be felt in this world, before being felt in the hereafter. Like the torment suffered by the people of Thamud, Pharaoh, and others. However, God will not inflict punishment on humans except as a reward and consequence of their own actions. Allah says:

"Whoever does righteousness - it is for his [own] soul; and whoever does evil [does it] against it. And your Lord is not ever unjust to [His] servants." (Fushshilat/41: 46)
text.38:
In this verse, Allah refutes the accusations of the disbelievers of Mecca. Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) never uttered imaginary words as a poet, but in reality, he was a bringer and supporter of the truth. The teachings of *tauhid* (monotheism) that he propagated need no further doubt, because the oneness of God is confirmed by sound reasoning and can be proven with clear evidence. It is not fitting to call the Messenger a poet when he brings the true teachings. The same teachings were also brought previously by the prophets of old.

The teachings of *tauhid* that he brought continue the teachings of *tauhid* brought by the previous prophets, and are by no means the creation of Muhammad (peace be upon him). So, the accusations against the Messenger as a poet and a madman are only due to hatred and denial. Allah will surely inflict a painful torment and severe punishment on the disbelievers who accuse the Messenger with that vile accusation. The punishment for those who deny the teachings of the messengers can be felt in this world, before being felt in the Hereafter. Such as the torment suffered by the people of Thamud, Pharaoh, and others. However, God will not send down punishment to humans except as a reward and consequence of their own actions. Allah says:

"Whoever does righteousness - it is for his [own] soul; and whoever does evil [does it] against it. And your Lord is not ever unjust to [His] servants." (Fushshilat/41: 46)

text.41:
Allah recounts the blessings bestowed upon those who are obedient to Allah and His Messenger. They sincerely perform good deeds, avoid all forms of disobedience and wickedness, and are cleansed from sin, always raising prayers and hopes to their Lord. These are the sincere servants of Allah, who will receive Paradise, as Allah states:

"Indeed, We have created man in the best of stature, Then We return him to the lowest of the low, Except for those who believe and do righteous deeds, for them is a reward uninterrupted." (at-Tin/95: 4-6)

And Allah says:

"By time, Indeed, mankind is in loss, Except for those who have believed and done righteous deeds and advised each other to truth and advised each other to patience." (al-'A.shr/103: 1-3)

This group of sincere servants of Allah will not feel torment, will not be questioned on the Day of Reckoning, and may even have their mistakes forgiven if there are any, and will be rewarded tenfold for each good deed they perform, or even greater than that by the will of Allah.

To them, Allah provides a predetermined provision, namely fruits of various kinds, fragrant in scent and delicious in taste, arousing the desire to enjoy them. They live in honor and receive service and respect.

From the verses above, it can be understood that the food in Paradise is provided for enjoyment and pleasure.

(43-44) In these verses, Allah further explains the servants of Allah who believe and do righteous deeds, and the Paradise full of blessings that has high places with rivers flowing beneath them, as Allah explained in His saying:

"And those who believe and do righteous deeds - We will surely house them in elevated chambers of Paradise beneath which rivers flow, wherein they will abide eternally. Excellent is the reward of the [righteous] workers." (al-'Ankabut/29: 58)

The people of Paradise sit on magnificent chairs facing each other so that they can get to know each other, and they converse about pleasant things that give them spiritual and physical satisfaction, as Allah explained with His saying:

"And they will approach one another, inquiring." (ath-thur/52: 25)

text.45:
After describing their food and dwellings, Allah then explains their drinks. Served by capable young servants, the inhabitants of Paradise enjoy delicious drinks, a glass of *khamr* that is very clear, like pure water, white in color, and delicious in taste. Some of their drinks are mixed with *zanjabil* (ginger) brought from a spring in Paradise called *Salsabil*, as explained in Allah's words:

"And they will be given to drink there a cup [of wine] mixed with ginger - From a spring there called Salsabil. And there will circulate among them young boys made eternal. When you see them, you would think them [as beautiful] scattered pearls." (al-Insan/76: 17-19)

The pleasure of the drinks provided by Allah in Paradise is a complete enjoyment for the inhabitants of Paradise. They are served with various kinds of abundant *khamr*, as if the *khamr* is taken from a clear spring that flows continuously; every time they ask, they will certainly get it. Allah also explains that the *khamr* in Paradise is very different from the *khamr* found in the world, in terms of clarity, color, smell, and taste.

Likewise, the effect of the drink on the physical and spiritual is different from the *khamr* of the world. The *khamr* of Paradise is not harmful and does not intoxicate.

text.51:
This verse explains the content of a conversation between the inhabitants of Paradise. One of them recounts to his friends that when he was alive in the world, he had a friend who asked him with a mocking tone about his belief in the Day of Resurrection and the Day of Judgment. His friend strongly denied the occurrence of resurrection from the grave. With astonishment and denial, his friend in the world said that it was impossible and very unreasonable that humans who had become soil and bones would be brought back to life from within the grave. And then, after that, an accounting would be made of his deeds during his life in the world.

According to the belief of that disbeliever, there is no further reckoning between evil and good, and between disbelief (kufr) and faith (iman). All of humanity's actions have already been accounted for in the world. Nevertheless, Allah affirms the existence of a final reckoning with His words:

"And not equal are the blind and the seeing, nor are those who believe and do good deeds and the evildoer. Little do you remember. Indeed, the Hour is coming - no doubt about it - but most of the people do not believe." (al-Mu'min/40: 58-59)

text.54:
The inhabitants of Paradise said to their friends so that they would be willing to observe the condition of the people of Paradise. Through this observation, they would surely increase in gratitude to Allah who had given them the *taufik* to follow the guidance of the prophets so that they were freed from the suffering of the fire of Hell.

Then the people of Paradise observed the condition of the inhabitants of Hell, and their disbelieving friends were shown to them, being in the midst of the blazing fire of Hell. At that time, the inhabitant of Paradise pointed at his friend who was in Hell, because when he was in the world, he was almost plunged into disbelief by his friend. But thanks to the *taufik* and *hidayah* of Allah bestowed upon him, he was spared from the influence of his disbelieving friend's understanding, and he was saved from the torment of Hell.

The conversation between the inhabitants of Paradise and Hell is also explained by Allah in His word:

And the companions of Paradise will call out to the companions of the Fire, "We have already found what our Lord promised us to be true. Have you found what your Lord promised to be true?" They will say, "Yes." Then an announcer will announce among them, "The curse of Allah is upon the wrongdoers." (al-A'raf/7: 44)

The word of Allah:

And the companions of the Fire will call to the companions of Paradise, "Pour upon us some water or from whatever Allah has provided you." They will say, "Indeed, Allah has forbidden them to the disbelievers." (al-A'raf/7: 50)

text.58:
In this verse, Allah explains the statement of the inhabitants of Paradise that they are very satisfied with the blessings and happiness in Paradise. They feel that living in Paradise means they will never experience death again, nor will they suffer torment. The only death they experienced was the death that left the life of this world. This is different from the disbelievers in Hell. Even though they have already experienced death in the world, they still desire a second death to end their suffering in Hell.

As for the inhabitants of Paradise, they never doubt the eternity of life in Paradise, because doubt causes anxiety, and anxiety is suffering. The inhabitants of Paradise declare again with full sincerity that all the pleasures they obtain, the deliciousness of food and drink, and all the spiritual satisfaction in Paradise, are a great victory. To achieve this great victory, according to them, requires sincere and devoted effort to Allah in this world.

text.62:
In this verse, Allah warns the disbelievers about the torment they will experience in Hell. They are presented with the question of which provision is better: the sustenance given to the inhabitants of Paradise, as mentioned above, or the fruit of the zaqqum tree, which is bitter and repulsive, prepared for them.

The question is meant as mockery towards them. However, they then question the zaqqum tree. How could it possibly grow in Hell, when Hellfire burns everything? For them, the zaqqum tree is a test and a trial, and in the Hereafter, it will be used as a means of torment. Allah says:

And We did not make the sight which We showed you except as a trial for the people, and [likewise] the accursed tree [zaqqum] mentioned in the Qur'an. And We frighten them, but it increases them only in great transgression. (al-Isra'/17: 60)

text.64:
Allah affirms that the zaqqum tree grows from the base of the blazing hellfire. Its branches tower high, as high as the flames of hell. The tree grows from within the fire and is also made from fire. Its shadow is like the heads of devils, very ugly and disgusting. The Arabs, in describing something very ugly and disgusting, liken it to devils, for example, like the heads of devils. However, the actual form of devils is unknown to anyone.

It is only that human imagination depicts them as very ugly. Conversely, in describing something beautiful, they liken it to angels. Therefore, God uses the word "angel" in describing the beauty of Yusuf in His word:

"This is not a human being; this is nothing but a noble angel." (Yusuf/12: 13)

text.66:
Then Allah explains that the food of the inhabitants of hell is the fruit of the Zaqqum tree. Even though they know its foul smell and bitter taste, because they are very hungry and there is no other food, they are forced to eat it until their stomachs are full.

Allah says:

"No food will there be for them but a bitter thorny plant, which will neither nourish nor satisfy hunger." (al-Gasyiyah/88: 6-7)

After eating the fruit of Zaqqum, they will certainly need a drink. So, they are provided with a drink mixed with very hot water that scorches their faces, as Allah describes in His saying:

"Indeed, We have prepared for the wrongdoers a fire whose walls will surround them. And if they call for relief, they will be relieved with water like murky oil, which scalds [their] faces. Wretched is the drink, and evil is the resting place." (al-Kahf/18: 29)

After they eat and drink, they are returned to the Jahim Hellfire, their original place.

"No food will there be for them but from a bitter, thorny plant, which will neither nourish nor satisfy hunger." (al-Ghashiyah/88: 6-7)

"Indeed, We have prepared for the wrongdoers a fire whose walls will surround them. And if they call for relief, they will be relieved with water like murky oil, which scalds [their] faces." (al-Kahf/18: 29)

After they eat and drink, they are returned to the Jahim hellfire, their original place.
text.68:
Then Allah explains that the food of the inhabitants of hell is the fruit of the zaqqum tree. Even though they know its foul smell and bitter taste, because they are very hungry and there is no other food, they are forced to eat it until their stomachs are full.

Allah says:

"No food will there be for them but a bitter thorny plant, which will neither nourish nor satisfy hunger." (al-Gasyiyah/88: 6-7)

After eating the zaqqum fruit, they will certainly need a drink. So, they are provided with a drink mixed with very hot water that scorches their faces, as Allah describes in His saying:

"For the wrongdoers, We have prepared a Fire whose (smoke and flames) will hem them in: if they call for help, they will be answered with a drink like molten metal, that will scald their faces." (al-Kahf/18: 29)

After they eat and drink, they are returned to the Jahim hell, their original place.
text.69:
In this verse, Allah explains the reason why the disbelievers are plunged into severe suffering and torment. It is because, after hearing the call conveyed by the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), they truly knew and realized the error of their ancestors without heeding the warnings of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him). They were too hasty and fanatical in following their ancestors, setting aside sound reasoning, as if they did not have time to contemplate the warnings of the Messenger.

Such behavior is highly reprehensible because it is not only detrimental to the perpetrators but also to subsequent generations. Backwardness and destruction will befall the ummah if the ability to think and initiate does not develop within them. Happiness can be achieved if the ummah continuously develops their thinking skills through observation and research into spiritual and material life.

text.71: In this verse, Allah explains that the majority of the nations of the past, before Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), had gone astray. They worshipped idols and associated partners with God, and often committed corruption on earth by waging wars. Their lives were based on desires and tyranny. Their leaders and state officials acted unjustly and oppressed the people with forced labor to build palaces and temples for idol worship and royal tombs. There were even those among them who claimed to be God, and the people were forced to worship them. Such are the stories of the nations of the past, such as the people of 'Ad, Thamud, King Nimrod, Pharaoh, and others.
text.72:
Then Allah sent to the previous communities prophets and messengers to establish the religion of monotheism (tauhid), to enjoin good (amar ma'ruf) and forbid evil (nahi munkar). These prophets were warners who strived to straighten the path of human life that deviated from the natural disposition (fitrah) of its creation. They showed their people the path of truth and falsehood, the path of good and evil, and reminded them of the punishment that would befall them if they refused to abandon their error and submit to the truth brought by the messengers.

But the prophets and messengers were opposed, denied, and antagonized; some of them were even persecuted to the point of being killed. The presence of the messengers among them was seen as a disturbance to the stability of their lives, so they remained in error and darkness. Eventually, the punishment of God came upon them, as Allah explained in His word:

"So as for Thamud, they were destroyed by the overpowering [thunderous] blast. And as for 'Aad, they were destroyed by a screaming, violent wind." (al-haqqah/69: 5-6)
text.73:
(73-74) In these verses, Allah calls upon the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) and his ummah to pay attention to the fate of the peoples who denied the messengers. Traces of their destruction can still be witnessed in the form of ancient relics. By paying attention to the history of past peoples, they will gain lessons to contemplate the warnings conveyed by the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him).

Not all the people within those communities denied the messengers of God who came to them and experienced punishment as retribution for their denial. But among them were servants of Allah who believed in Him with sincere hearts, performed righteous deeds, obeyed all His commands and prohibitions. They were saved from punishment and granted happiness in this world and the hereafter.

But among them were servants of Allah who believed in Him with sincerity, performed righteous deeds, and obeyed all His commands and prohibitions. They were saved from punishment and granted happiness in this world and the hereafter.
text.75:
This verse explains that Prophet Noah prayed to God to grant him assistance against the threats and persecution from his people. They even intended to kill him when he called them to the religion of monotheism (tauhid).

Despite Prophet Noah calling his people day and night, secretly and openly, for quite a long time, only a few of them believed. Every time they were given warnings and teachings, they grew further away from the religion and their hostility towards Prophet Noah intensified. This caused Prophet Noah great disappointment, and he prayed to God that those disbelievers be destroyed immediately. Allah's word:

"And Noah said, "My Lord, do not leave upon the earth from among the disbelievers an inhabitant. Indeed, if You leave them, they will mislead Your servants and not beget except [a continuous line of] wicked and ungrateful [children]." (Nuh/71: 26-27)

Allah answered Prophet Noah's prayer. Allah mentions Himself as the Best of those who answer prayers. This acceptance was greatly hoped for by Prophet Noah at that time because his people denied and opposed him.
text.76:
Then, the types of Prophet Noah's prayers that were answered are explained, including: First, Allah saved Noah and those who believed with him, including some of his sons, from a great disaster, namely a violent hurricane accompanied by a great flood. One of his sons drowned. Those who survived the great flood were those who were on the ship. Allah's word:

"Then We saved him and those with him in the laden ship. Then after that We drowned those who remained behind." (ash-Shu'ara'/26: 119-120)

Second, Allah made the descendants of Prophet Noah the people who would continue his lineage, and those who rebelled and opposed his call were destroyed, as Prophet Noah requested in his prayer.

Third, Allah immortalized praise and a fragrant name for Noah among the prophets who came later and mankind until the end of time. He is famous among Muslims, including one of the five messengers called *ulul 'azmi*, which means people who have steadfastness of heart. The other four messengers are Ibrahim, Musa, Isa, and Muhammad saw.

text.79:
Then, the greeting of peace upon Noah, "Salamun 'ala Nuhin," is mentioned as an instruction for the angels, jinn, and humans so that they too will offer greetings of peace to Noah until the Day of Judgment. Allah says:

It was said, "O Noah, descend with peace from Us and blessings upon you and upon nations [descending] from those with you." (Hud/11: 48)

With the greetings of peace for Noah by humankind from time to time, the name of Prophet Noah will remain fragrant and remembered for all time.
text.80:
The perpetuation of Noah's name with the greeting of peace upon him is a form of honor for him, and a recompense for the good deeds he performed and his tireless struggle in upholding the word of Tawhid, day and night, openly and secretly, for hundreds of years. It is also a reward for his patience in enduring physical and mental suffering while conveying the message amidst his people.

What motivated Prophet Noah to work hard in guiding his people was the purity and sincerity of his devotion to Allah, accompanied by the steadfastness of faith in his soul. Therefore, Allah declares that he was truly His servant full of faith. The highlighting of faith in the person of Noah as a praised messenger is to show the great significance of faith, because it is the foundation of all good deeds.

As for the rest of Noah's people, who refused to believe in the religion of Tawhid that was conveyed to them, they were destroyed by a great storm and flood until not one of them remained, and there were no traces of their legacy to be remembered. They vanished from the annals of human history.

text.83: This verse explains that Prophet Ibrahim was among the descendants and successors of the message of Prophet Nuh. He followed in the footsteps of Prophet Nuh in upholding the teachings of *tauhid* (monotheism), believing in the existence of the Day of Judgment, striving to spread the religion of *tauhid* and belief in the Day of Judgment, carrying out *amar ma'ruf nahi munkar* (enjoining good and forbidding evil), and being steadfast and patient in facing the hostility of the disbelieving people.
text.84: This verse further emphasizes the purity of Prophet Ibrahim's soul. He directed his soul towards the One God with complete sincerity, free from polytheism, detached from the interests of worldly life, and far from other negative feelings that could disturb his soul.
text.85:
Then Allah reminds us of the story of Prophet Ibrahim when, with his pure and sincere soul, he asked his parents and his people why they worshipped idols. This should not have happened if they were willing to think about the idols they worshipped, which neither benefited nor harmed them:

Allah says:

"(Remember) when he (Ibrahim) said to his father, "O my father, why do you worship that which does not hear and does not see and cannot avail you in anything? O my father, indeed there has come to me of knowledge that which has not come to you, so follow me; I will guide you to an even path." (Maryam/19: 42-43)

Prophet Ibrahim firmly stated to them that their attitude of wanting to worship other than Allah was incorrect, based on untrue reasons. To worship the unseen God requires guidance; otherwise, the worship would certainly be based on fantasies and the tastes of each individual's mind. This would lead to many forms of worship to God according to each person's conception of God.

In the Jahiliyyah era, each Arab tribe had its own idols and statues according to their respective thoughts. Similarly, in the time of Prophet Ibrahim, there were many idols they worshipped as a result of the imagination of his people at that time. Prophet Ibrahim, who was given knowledge by Allah that was not given to his people, certainly tried to change this situation. Then he raised various questions to his people so that they were forced to think about themselves, what was the basis of their assumption that they did not worship the Lord, the Creator and Ruler of the universe, but instead associated partners with Him in the form of statues and idols. In fact, they could not give a reason to refuse to worship the One God.

text.88:
Then Ibrahim cast his gaze upon the stars, thinking deeply about how to confront his people who stubbornly persisted in worshipping idols, solely on the grounds of upholding ancestral heritage. Even though he had already given them warnings and teachings, as Allah states:

(Remember) when he (Ibrahim) said to his father and his people, "What are these statues to which you are so devoted?" They said, "We found our forefathers worshipping them." (al-Anbiya'/21: 52-53)

After thinking and considering earnestly, he decided to take a dangerous action, which was to destroy all those idols.

At one point, Ibrahim's people came to invite him to attend their festival. He politely declined their invitation, citing health problems as the reason. Besides avoiding attending their festival, Prophet Ibrahim intended to carry out his plan to destroy the idols and openly declare his opposition to idol worshippers. His people were unaware of Prophet Ibrahim's plan and did not suspect him. Nor did his attitude suggest that he was being dishonest in his words. Thus, their festival took place without Ibrahim's presence. The reason of impaired health for not attending his people's invitation, even though he was not actually sick, is not considered a forbidden lie in religion. That Ibrahim deceived his people is indeed true. The Messenger of Allah said:

Ibrahim did not lie except three times, two of which were about Allah, namely his words "I am sick" and "Actually, the biggest one did it," and his words about his wife Sarah, "This is my sister." (Narrated by Ahmad and al-Syaikhan from Abu Hurairah)

Prophet Ibrahim's words that his health was impaired, spoken in front of his people, were actually to avoid attending his people's festival.

Ibrahim said, "Indeed, you and your forefathers have been in manifest error." They said, "Have you come to us with the truth, or are you of those who jest?" Ibrahim said, "Rather, your Lord is the Lord of the heavens and the earth who created them, and I am of those who testify to that. And [I swear] by Allah, I will surely devise a plan against your idols after you have turned and gone away."

During the festival, Prophet Ibrahim took the opportunity to destroy his people's idols. Ibrahim's words that the biggest idol was the one who broke them were spoken when he was questioned by his people about the destruction of the idols. In reality, he himself broke the idols, but he said that the biggest idol broke them, even though his people realized that the idols could not do anything.

Both of Ibrahim's statements were made in the context of his struggle to uphold the word of *tauhid* (oneness of God). As for the third statement, which was "Sarah is my sister," even though she was actually his wife, it was spoken in front of the king when the king desired Sarah.

Thus, the three statements made by Ibrahim were not blameworthy lies in the eyes of religion and society. The Messenger of Allah explained that these three statements of Prophet Ibrahim were justified by religion, as the Prophet said:

The Messenger of Allah said about Ibrahim's three statements, saying that there is no lie except for things that are justified by the religion of Allah. (Narrated by at-Tirmidzi from Abu Sa'id)

text.91:
After his people left, Ibrahim secretly went to the place of the idols, then said mockingly, "Why do the idols not eat the food that is served before them?" The offerings were presented by their worshippers on certain days to seek blessings.

Of course, the idols did not say anything. However, Ibrahim asked again, "Why do the idols not answer my question?" Then he struck the idols hard until they were destroyed, except for the largest idol. This event aroused the anger of his people. Then they searched for the perpetrator and obtained information that Ibrahim had broken the idols. They quickly met Ibrahim and asked him if it was true that he had broken the idols. Ibrahim evaded the question and said that the largest idol was the one who broke them. After hearing Ibrahim's words, his people lowered their heads and reflected on themselves. There was nothing they could do to the large idol, which they had been worshipping all this time.

After seeing his people stunned and lowering their heads, Prophet Ibrahim then said to them again that it was not fitting for them to worship idols that they carved with their own hands. They should be grateful that from among themselves, a person was born who had intellect, who prevented the worship of those idols. Prophet Ibrahim reiterated that the only one worthy of worship was Allah who created them and their idols. The Creator God is more worthy of worship than His creation. Allah says:

He (Ibrahim) said, "Do you worship besides Allah that which cannot benefit you at all or harm you? Woe to you and to what you worship besides Allah. Then will you not use reason?" (al-Anbiya'/21: 66-67)

The reasons conveyed by Prophet Ibrahim could not be refuted with reasons either, so they resorted to violence, challenging Ibrahim. They planned to kill Ibrahim. Then a building was erected to be used as a place to burn Prophet Ibrahim. When the building was completed and the fire was lit, Prophet Ibrahim was thrown into it. Allah says:

They said, "Burn him and support your gods - if you are to act." (al-Anbiya'/21: 68)

Ibrahim's people truly wanted him to perish and be burned to ashes in the bonfire. However, Allah willed to save him from destruction by commanding the fire not to burn Ibrahim, as His saying:

We (Allah) said, "O fire, be coolness and safety upon Ibrahim." (al-Anbiya'/21: 69)

Thus, Prophet Ibrahim was saved from the bonfire and gained victory over the disbelievers.

After he no longer saw any signs of his people's willingness to believe, he intended to leave them, to migrate from his homeland. Perhaps in a new place, he could worship God without interference from the disbelieving people, and could develop religion with the *taufik* and *hidayah* of Allah. As for the country he was heading to, it was Baitulmakdis.

text.100:
This verse recounts that Prophet Ibrahim, in his travels, pleaded to God to be granted a righteous and obedient child who could assist him in conveying the message (da'wah), accompany him on his journeys, and be a companion in his loneliness.

The presence of this child would be a replacement for the family and people he had left behind. This request of Prophet Ibrahim was granted by Allah. He was given the glad tidings that Allah would bestow upon him a son possessing the quality of great patience.

This quality of patience emerges at the age of puberty (balig). Because in childhood, qualities such as patience, steadfastness, and open-mindedness are rarely found. This adolescent son was Ismail, the first son of Ibrahim, whose mother was Hajar, Ibrahim's second wife. The second son was Ishaq, born later after Ismail from Ibrahim's first wife, Sarah.

text.102:
Then, this verse explains the heavy trial for Ibrahim (Abraham). Allah commanded him to slaughter his only son as a sacrifice to Allah. At that time, Ismail (Ishmael) was approaching puberty or adolescence, an age when a child can help his parents with their work. According to al-Farra', Ismail's age at that time was 13 years old. Ibrahim, with a sad heart, told Ismail about the command of God that was conveyed to him through a dream. He asked his son's opinion regarding the command. The command of God concerned the slaughter of his own son, which was a great trial for both parent and child.

After listening to the command of God, Ismail, with all humility, said to his father to carry out all that was commanded to him. He would be obedient, willing, and sincere in accepting God's decree and upholding all His commands and surrendering to Him. Ismail, who was still very young, told his parents that he would not be afraid to face the trial, would not hesitate to accept God's *qada* and *qadar*. He would patiently and steadfastly endure the suffering of the slaughter. Ismail's attitude was highly praised by Allah in His word:

And mention in the Book (the Qur'an) Ismail. Indeed, he was true to his promise, and he was a messenger and a prophet. (Maryam/19: 54)
text.103:
When both had surrendered to God and submitted to all His will, then Ishmael knelt and prostrated his face to the ground so that Abraham could no longer see his son's face. Ishmael deliberately did this so that his father would not see his face. Thus, Prophet Abraham could quickly complete his task. Prophet Abraham began to draw his knife to slaughter him. At that time, the voice of an angel came from behind him, sent to Abraham, saying that the purpose of Allah's command through the dream had been fulfilled by Ishmael being laid face down to be slaughtered. Abraham's action was a sincere obedience to Allah's command and decree. After the angel delivered the revelation, both of them rejoiced and gave thanks to Allah who had bestowed blessings and strength of soul to face that difficult test. To both of them, Allah gave a reward and recompense commensurate with their sincere obedience. They were able to overcome paternal feelings solely to uphold Allah's command.

According to a narration by Ahmad from Ibn 'Abbas, when Abraham was ordered to perform the *sa'i* ritual, Satan came to tempt him. Satan tried to race with him, but Abraham managed to overtake him to Jumrah Aqabah. Satan tempted him again, but Abraham stoned him seven times until he fled. At the time of *jumratul wustha*, Satan came again to tempt him, but Abraham stoned him seven times. Then Abraham told his son to prostrate his face so that he could be slaughtered immediately. Ishmael was wearing a white *gamis* (long robe) at that time. He said to his father, "O my father, there is no cloth to shroud me except this *gamis*, so take it off so that you can shroud me with my *gamis*." Then Abraham began to take off the *gamis*, but at that moment there was a voice behind him calling, "O Abraham, you have fulfilled your dream truthfully." Abraham immediately turned around, and suddenly a white ram was in front of him.

text.106:
In this verse, it is emphasized that what Ibrahim and his son experienced was a very heavy trial. Indeed, it is Allah's right to test the servants He wills with the form of trial He chooses, in the form of heavy burdens and obligations. Once the trial has been decreed, no one can refuse or avoid it. Behind these heavy trials, there are certainly wisdoms and secrets that are beyond human comprehension.

Ismail, who was initially made a sacrifice to test Ibrahim's obedience, was replaced by Allah with a large, clean white ram without any defects. This event of Prophet Ibrahim slaughtering a goat became the basis for the *kurban* (sacrifice) worship to draw closer to Allah, which was continued by the *sharia* of Prophet Muhammad. This *kurban* worship is carried out on the day of Eid al-Adha/Eid al-Kurban or on the days of *tasyriq*, which are three consecutive days after Eid al-Kurban, the 11th, 12th, and 13th of Zulhijah.

The sacrificial animals consist of livestock such as camels, cows, buffaloes, and goats. It is indicated that the sacrificial animal should not have physical defects, should not be sick, and should be of sufficient age. Slaughtering animals for *kurban* is *sunnah muakkadah* (a highly recommended sunnah).

Allah says:

"So pray to your Lord and sacrifice [to Him alone]." (al-Kautsar/108: 2)

With the enactment of *kurban* worship in Islam, the event of Ibrahim sacrificing his son will be remembered forever and followed by his followers. *Kurban* worship also enlivens the Islamic religion because the *kurban* meat is distributed to the community, especially to the poor and needy.

text.108:
These verses explain that humanity from various religions (heavenly religions) and groups loves Prophet Ibrahim throughout time. Followers of Judaism, Christianity, and Islam respect him and praise his name, even the Arab polytheists acknowledge that their religion also follows the religion of Islam (Ibrahim).

Thus, Allah fulfilled the request of Prophet Ibrahim when he prayed:

"And grant me a reputation of honor among later generations, And place me among the inheritors of the Garden of Pleasure." (ash-Shu'ara'/26: 84-85)

Then Allah bestowed upon Ibrahim the honor that He gave peace to him. This peace for Ibrahim continues to live in the midst of humanity, even among the angels. Thus, there are three rewards that Allah has bestowed upon him, namely a great ram that was brought to him as a substitute for his son, the perpetuation that gives fragrance to his name throughout time, and the greeting of peace from God and humanity. That is how Allah rewards His servants who do good. All these rewards are in return for his obedience in carrying out Allah's commands.

Ibrahim achieved this high achievement because of the encouragement of strong faith and the sincerity of his worship to Allah, so that he is included among His believing servants.

text.112:
This verse explains that Allah conveyed good news to Ibrahim about the birth of a son from his first wife, Sarah. This news was delivered by angels, disguised as humans, who visited his house when Sarah was already old. Allah says:

So he (Ibrahim) felt apprehension about them. They said, "Do not be afraid." And they gave him good tidings of (the birth of) a knowledgeable son (Isaac). Then his wife came forward, crying aloud, and struck her face, saying, "(I am) an old woman who is barren!" They said, "Thus has your Lord said. Indeed, He is the Wise, the Knowing." (Adz-Dzariyat/51: 28-30)

The angels also informed him that Isaac would be a prophet and from him would descend Jacob, who would also be a prophet. Both were among Allah's righteous servants, people who loved to do good and bring benefit to their people.

Regarding the news of Isaac's birth, Allah also mentions it in other surahs, such as in Surah Hud/11: 69-73, Surah Maryam/19: 49, and Surah al-Anbiya'/21: 72.

Among the scholars of tafsir, there is an opinion that it was Isaac who was to be sacrificed by Ibrahim to fulfill God's command, not his older brother Ismail. Ibn Kathir, in his tafsir, quotes al-Bagawi stating that Umar, Ali, Ibn Mas'ud, and al-'Abbas (Ibn 'Abbas) held the opinion that Isaac was the one to be sacrificed. The source of this opinion is from Jews who converted to Islam. According to Ibn Kathir, all opinions stating that Isaac was to be sacrificed originate from Ka'bul-Akhbar. He was a Jew who converted to Islam during the time of Caliph Umar and recited the contents of the Torah to Umar.

Speaking about the difference of opinion regarding this sacrifice, Ibn al-Qayyim, in his book Zadul Ma'ad, says that the correct opinion, according to the scholars among the Companions, the Tabi'in, and later scholars, is that it was Ismail who was to be sacrificed by Ibrahim. The opinion that the sacrifice was Isaac is very wrong from various perspectives. Ibn Taimiyah, as quoted by Ibn al-Qayyim, said, "This opinion was launched by the People of the Book, even though it contradicts the contents of their own book."

In the Torah, it is said that Allah commanded Ibrahim to sacrifice his firstborn son. Both Muslims and the People of the Book agree that the firstborn son was Ismail. However, they later distorted the contents of the Torah by including the words: Sacrifice your son Isaac. According to Ibn Taimiyah, "That is an addition resulting from the distortion of the Jews, because that addition contradicts the words 'firstborn son,' their sole envy of the descendants of Ismail who obtained glory, causing them to falsify the contents of this book."

The second reason put forward by Ibn Taimiyah is based on the information in the Qur'an:

And We gave her good tidings of Isaac and after Isaac, Jacob. (Hud/11: 71)

Allah informed Sarah of the birth of Isaac, who would have a son named Jacob. Therefore, it is impossible for Allah to announce the birth of Isaac and then command him to be sacrificed, even though it has been stated that Jacob would descend from him. How could Jacob be born into the world if his father was made a sacrifice, even though it was promised that he would be born from the descendants of Isaac? So, if that is the case, it was not Isaac who was to be sacrificed, but Ismail.

The third reason Ibn Taimiyah points to is the story of Ibrahim and his son in Surah As-Saffat. In verses 103-111, it is narrated that when Ibrahim was about to sacrifice his son to carry out Allah's command, a voice came from behind him, calling out that Ibrahim, by his actions, was considered to have carried out Allah's command. For his sincere obedience, Ibrahim received reward and praise from Allah.

After that event, Allah then informed Ibrahim about the birth of Isaac, as a reward from Allah for his patience and obedience. Thus, it certainly was not Isaac who was to be sacrificed, because he had not yet been born.

The fourth reason: that the event of Ibrahim about to sacrifice his son took place near Mecca, no one doubts. Therefore, the sacrifice (Qurban) is held on the day of Eid al-Adha. Also, the Sa'i between Safa and Marwa and the throwing of the Jamarat in the Hajj pilgrimage are memories of the events that befell Ismail and his mother. As is known, Ismail and his mother lived in Mecca. The time and place of the Qurban ritual are always connected with the Baitulharam. If it were Isaac who was to be sacrificed, then the Qurban ceremony would have been held in the place where Isaac lived (Syria), not in Mecca.

These are some of the reasons put forward by Ibn Taimiyah to refute the opinion that Isaac was the one to be sacrificed. (See also the information contained in the vocabulary of Ibrahim and Ismail)
text.113:
This verse explains that blessings and prosperity in this world and the hereafter were bestowed by Allah upon Ibrahim and Ishak. From them both came a widespread progeny, and from their descendants arose many prophets and messengers. Muslims are instructed to always beseech God in every prayer that Ibrahim and his family be granted blessings and happiness.

From their descendants who spread widely across the earth, some did good, and some were unjust to themselves. Those who did good are those who believed in Allah, upheld His commands, and avoided His prohibitions in accordance with the guidance of His messengers. As for those who were unjust to themselves, they are those who denied the religion brought by the messengers and committed wickedness and disobedience.

This verse reminds mankind that from a noble and honorable family, there is the possibility of good or bad descendants being born. Lineage or race does not guarantee nobility or degradation for descendants, as it still depends on the efforts of education and upbringing of children. Ibrahim, Ishak, and Yakub are people who Allah has declared to have reached a level of glory. Allah says:

"And remember Our servants, Ibrahim, Ishak, and Yakub - those of enduring strength and [profound] vision." (shad/38: 45)

However, the descendants of Yakub, called Bani Israil, both in ancient and modern history, have experienced much suffering and humiliation. The reason is because they were unjust to themselves, disobedient to their ancestors, and abandoned the guidance of Allah and the prophets.
text.114:
Allah explains that He has bestowed upon Musa and Harun a great favor, namely prophethood and messengership. They were also entrusted with the noble task of leading the Children of Israel and freeing them from the slavery of Pharaoh, and returning them to their homeland. This task was very difficult. If it were not for the help of Allah, they would surely have perished.

The story of Musa is mentioned most often in the Qur'an. As a messenger, he has many similarities with the Prophet Muhammad, as Allah explains in Surah al-Muzzammil/73 verse 15.
text.115:
In this verse, Allah explains six blessings that have been bestowed upon Musa and Harun. These blessings are:

First, Musa, Harun, and their people were saved from a great disaster. For a long time, the Israelites lived in Egypt under the rule of Pharaoh. They were forced to do hard labor and were treated as slaves. Even their male children were killed in large numbers, and the female children were allowed to live, upon the orders and prophecies of the sorcerers surrounding Pharaoh. They were almost annihilated if Musa and Harun had not come to save them.

Second, in addition to being saved from Pharaoh's pursuit, Pharaoh even drowned at the bottom of the sea, and the Children of Israel also succeeded in defeating other enemies and reclaiming their lands. They were able to gather again the wealth they had acquired throughout their lives, becoming a strong nation, and possessing strength and power to the point of having a large state like in the time of King Talut and Daud. Allah says:

"So they defeated them by permission of Allah, and David killed Goliath, and Allah gave him kingship and wisdom and taught him of what He willed..." (al-Baqarah/2: 251)
text.116:

First, Musa, Harun, and their people were saved from a great disaster. For a long time, the Israelites lived in Egypt under the rule of Pharaoh. They were forced to do hard labor and were treated as slaves. Even many of their sons were killed and their daughters were allowed to live on the orders and predictions of the sorcerers surrounding Pharaoh. They were almost wiped out if Musa and Harun had not come to save them.

Second, in addition to being saved from Pharaoh's pursuit, Pharaoh even drowned at the bottom of the sea, the Children of Israel also succeeded in defeating other enemies and reclaiming their lands. They were able to gather again the wealth they had acquired throughout their lives, becoming a strong nation, and possessing strength and power to the point of having a large state like in the time of King Talut and Daud. Allah says:

"So they defeated them by permission of Allah, and David killed Goliath, and Allah gave him the kingdom and wisdom and taught him of what He willed..." (al-Baqarah/2: 251)
text.117:
These two verses explain the blessings that Allah bestowed upon the Children of Israel. While the previous two types of blessings were material blessings, the following two are spiritual blessings, namely two kinds of divine gifts that saved and elevated their souls and morals.

Third, Allah gave Moses and Aaron the Torah, a very clear book containing provisions and guidance for happiness in both this world and the hereafter. Allah says:

"And We had already given Moses and Aaron the criterion [i.e., the Torah] and a light and a reminder for the righteous." (al-Anbiya'/21: 48)

This book was bequeathed to the Children of Israel to be used as a guide in their lives. Allah says:

"And We did certainly give Moses guidance, and We caused the Children of Israel to inherit the Scripture, As guidance and a reminder for those of understanding." (al-Mu'min/40: 53-54)

Fourth, Allah showed them both the path of truth leading to true happiness. With their intellect, they both implemented and followed divine guidance, both in matters of faith (akidah) and dealings (muamalah), and Allah continued to bestow upon them His success (taufik) and protection.

text.119:
Then Allah explains another favor which is a glory He bestowed upon Moses and Aaron, just as Allah bestowed upon Noah and Abraham. That glory is:

Allah immortalized the fragrant mention of their names, which are fragrant among the prophets and mankind throughout time. Likewise, praise and prayers continue to be given to them.

Allah mentions peace be upon Moses and Aaron so that the angels, jinn, and humans will also mention peace upon them. With the utterance of peace, their names will remain fragrant forever.

text.121:
These two verses explain that the great blessings mentioned above, such as victory over enemies, divine guidance, glories, and so on, are thanks to the good deeds they performed, and their sacrifices and suffering in striving for the establishment of the religion of monotheism (tauhid). Thus, Allah rewards those who do good for the benefit of fellow human beings with rewards in this world and the hereafter.

What motivated them to perform good deeds and be willing to endure suffering was the faith that blossomed in their hearts. From the foundation of strong faith, noble deeds are born, which is why Allah affirms that they are servants of Allah who believe.

text.123: In this verse, Allah affirms that Ilyas (Elijah) was a messenger sent by Allah. According to ath-Thabari, Ilyas was the son of Yasin bin Finhas bin 'Iyzar bin Prophet Harun (Aaron), the brother of Prophet Musa (Moses). His prophetic period was after the prophethood of Prophet Sulaiman (Solomon). He was sent by Allah to the Children of Israel (Bani Israil) when his people no longer worshipped Allah, but worshipped idols. Their kings also supported this idolatrous religion, even building special places for slaughtering animals to be offered to the idols.
text.124: Prophet Ilyas warned his people to be pious to Allah, which is to carry out all His commands and avoid all His prohibitions. Piety (Taqwa) is the core teaching of the prophets up to Prophet Muhammad. If they are pious, they will be happy in this world and the hereafter, but if they remain disbelievers, they will be afflicted with a severe torment from Allah.
text.125: The Prophet Elijah asked them to abandon the worship of idols which they named Ba'l. According to some scholars, Ba'l was the name of an idol of the Phoenicians in pre-Christian times. Others say that Ba'l was the name of an idol worshiped by the inhabitants of the city of Ba'labak in western Damascus. The Prophet Elijah rebuked them, asking why they worshiped that idol, because the idol did not create and could not do anything. The one who deserves to be made God and worshiped is the one who creates, not the Ba'l idol which cannot do anything.
text.126:
Prophet Ilyas affirmed that the Almighty Creator is Allah. Allah is the One who created them and their ancestors. Therefore, Allah is their true Lord and also the Lord of their ancestors, namely Prophet Ibrahim, Prophet Ismail, Prophet Ishaq, and Prophet Yaqub. Before his death, Prophet Yaqub had received a promise from his children that they would only worship Allah, as explained in the Qur'an:

"Or were you witnesses when death approached Jacob, when he said to his sons, "What will you worship after me?" They said, "We will worship your God and the God of your fathers, Abraham, Ishmael and Isaac - one God. And we are Muslims [in submission] to Him." (al-Baqarah/2: 133)

By worshipping the Ba'l idol, it meant that they had violated the pledge of their ancestors.
text.127:
This verse explains that the people of Prophet Ilyas opposed him. They considered Prophet Ilyas to be a liar in the message he conveyed. Therefore, they refused to return to the religion of monotheism (tauhid). Because they continued to choose shirk (associating partners with God) and did not return to the religion of monotheism, they were allowed to remain as they were in this world, but in the Hereafter they will be dragged forcibly into Hell.

Those who do good deeds sincerely are kept away from Hell. They are called al-mukhlishin 'the sincere ones.' After their sincerity in doing good deeds becomes so strong that it becomes their nature, then Allah welcomes that sincerity so that He makes them people who have been fully accepted for their sincerity. Such a person is called al-mukhlashin 'those whom He has purified/chosen.' In the Qur'an, such people are not affected by the temptations of Satan, as Satan himself acknowledges:

He (Iblis) said, "My Lord, because You have put me in error, I will surely make (disobedience) attractive to them on earth, and I will mislead them all, except for Your chosen servants among them." (al-Hijr/15: 39-40)

text.129: This verse explains the glory that Allah gave to the Prophet Ilyas for his tireless struggle in conveying the da'wah to mankind. This glory is the same as the glory given to the Prophets Nuh, Ibrahim, Musa, and Harun, namely that their names are remembered throughout time by religious communities. Among these is the praise of their names in the Al-Qur'an, which endures until the end of time.
text.130:
Allah sends greetings to Ilyasin (the plural form of Ilyas), namely Prophet Ilyas and those who accepted and supported the teachings he conveyed. The greeting from Allah is an assurance of everlasting safety and well-being from Allah for Prophet Ilyas and his followers in this world and the hereafter.

text.131: In this verse, Allah affirms that the honor bestowed upon Prophet Ilyas (Elijah) was due to the good deeds he had performed. He had striven to uphold the religion of monotheism (tauhid) and to straighten the path of life followed by his people, the Children of Israel (Bani Israil). He had preached with full sacrifice, sincerely and purely for Allah's sake. His concern was not for himself, but for how his people could believe and do good in their lives.
text.132: Allah praises Prophet Ilyas because he is among His believing servants. He was truly a believer, dedicating himself to Him. Because of his faith, Prophet Ilyas was able to make great sacrifices for the good of his people. Indeed, faith needs to be proven with good deeds, and Prophet Ilyas has proven it.
text.133:
In this verse, it is explained that Prophet Lut (Lot) was a messenger of Allah. He was a contemporary of Prophet Ibrahim (Abraham). He was sent by Allah to a land called Sodom in the region of Palestine. The inhabitants of this land were known for their homosexual behavior. Prophet Lut tried to make them aware by stating that their actions were deviant and cursed by Allah. Allah says:

"And (remember) when Lot said to his people, "Indeed, you commit immorality never committed before you by anyone in the worlds. Do you approach men and obstruct the road and commit in your meetings [every] evil?" And the answer of his people was not but that they said, "Bring us the punishment of Allah, if you should be of the truthful." (al-'Ankabut/29: 28-29)

But the warnings and advice of Prophet Lut were ignored by them, and they even challenged Prophet Lut to immediately ask Allah to bring punishment upon them.
text.134:
Because they continued to disobey and even challenge, Allah sent down His punishment. In these verses, Allah explains that He saved Prophet Lut (Lot) and his followers who believed, and destroyed those who disobeyed, including his wife. The way Allah saved Prophet Lut and his followers was by commanding them to leave the land in the middle of the night, so that before dawn they had to be outside the land, as depicted in the following verse:

They (the angels) said, "O Lot, indeed, we are messengers of your Lord; never will they reach you. So set out with your family during a portion of the night and let not any among you look back - except your wife. Indeed, she will be struck by that which strikes them. Indeed, their appointment is [for] the morning. Is not the morning near?" (Hud/11: 81).

When dawn arrived, the promised disaster came, which was that the land was overturned, so that those who disbelieved were buried in the earth. Allah says:

So when Our command came, We made the highest part [of the city] its lowest and rained upon them stones of layered burning clay, Marked from your Lord. And it is not from the wrongdoers far. (Hud/11: 82-83)

In addition, the land was hit by a great storm carrying stones, destroying and burying the land, as informed in another verse:

The people of Lot denied the warnings. Indeed, We sent upon them a storm of stones, except the family of Lot - We saved them before dawn. (al-Qamar/54: 33-34)

Because Prophet Lut, some of his family, and his believing followers were already outside their city, they were all saved. The one who was not saved was an old woman, namely his wife. She obeyed her disbelieving people more than she followed Prophet Lut. Therefore, she remained in the land, and thus became a victim.

text.137:
In this verse, Allah swt directs His address to the disbelievers of Mecca, stating that they constantly pass by the land of Sodom, which has been destroyed and partially remains in ruins, due to its location on the trade route between Mecca and Syria. This route is frequently traversed by their trade caravans. They pass through it in the morning or evening. From the ruins, they can estimate the magnitude of the event. They, and anyone after them, should take a lesson from this event and believe, as stated in the following verse:

"And indeed, it is by a highway still (traveled). Indeed in that is a sign for the believers." (al-Hijr/15: 76-77)

But why do they still not take a lesson from that event, and why do they still refuse to believe?

text.139: In this verse, Allah affirms that Prophet Yunus (Jonah) was a messenger of Allah. He was sent to the land of Nineveh (Nainawa), one of the cities of the Assyrian kingdom on the banks of the Tigris River (the Mosul area, Iraq today). He tried to make his people aware not to deify idols, and invited them to believe in and worship the One God, namely Allah swt, but they opposed him.
text.140:
Because of the extreme resistance of the people of Prophet Yunus to the call to embrace the religion of monotheism, Prophet Yunus became angry and threatened them that they would soon be struck by disaster as a punishment from Allah. He then left them, and soon after, the threat proved true, as they saw the signs of the torment from afar in the form of thick, black clouds. Before the torment arrived, they left their village with their wives and children towards the desert. There, they repented and prayed that Allah would not send down His torment. Their repentance was accepted by Allah and their prayers were answered, as stated in another verse:

"Then has there been any town (community) that believed, so that its faith benefited it, except the people of Jonah? When they believed, We removed from them the torment of disgrace in the life of the world and gave them enjoyment for a time." (Yunus/10: 98)

Meanwhile, Prophet Yunus, in his flight, boarded a ship laden with goods and passengers. In the middle of the sea, the ship was hit by a large wave, which they believed to be a sign that there was a runaway slave on the ship. That person had to be thrown overboard. Because no one wanted to jump into the sea voluntarily, a lottery was held by throwing arrows, as was the custom of the people at that time. Whoever's arrow stuck meant he lost and had to jump into the sea. In the lottery, Prophet Yunus' arrow stuck. However, the passengers did not want to throw him into the sea by force because they respected him. Another lottery was held, but Prophet Yunus still lost. It was held again, and the same thing happened. Finally, Prophet Yunus himself took off his clothes and jumped into the sea.

Allah then commanded a very large fish to swallow Prophet Yunus, but not to eat him. Inside the belly of the large fish, Prophet Yunus certainly suffered. He felt imprisoned. He felt tormented for having left his people. He then repented.

text.143:
In his repentance, he frequently glorified Allah and prayed. The wording of the tasbih that Prophet Yunus repeatedly recited is mentioned in Surah al-Anbiya'/21: 87:

"Then he cried out in the darkness, "There is no deity except You; exalted are You. Indeed, I have been of the wrongdoers." (al-Anbiya'/21: 87)

In his tasbih, Prophet Yunus truly acknowledged that God is only Allah. Allah is free from all imperfections and attributes that are not befitting of Him. And he admitted that he had done wrong. Within those acknowledgements was a sincere prayer that he be released from the torment of being imprisoned in the belly of the fish.

Allah affirms that if he had not glorified and prayed like that, he would have remained in the belly of the fish until the Day of Judgment. It was because of his tasbih and prayer that Allah released him from the belly of the fish, as stated in another verse:

So We responded to him and saved him from the distress. And thus do We save the believers. (al-Anbiya'/21: 88)

text.145: After one, or three, or several days, according to some opinions, the Prophet Jonah was in the belly of the great fish, Allah commanded the fish to vomit him out onto a barren area where nothing grew. Because he had been in the belly of the fish for some time, the Prophet Jonah's condition was very weak. To save him from the heat of the sun, Allah grew a *yaqthin* tree (a type of gourd) beside him. The leaves of the tree protected him and its fruit became his food.

Because he had been inside the fish's belly for some time, the Prophet Yunus' condition was very weak. To save him from the scorching heat of the sun, Allah caused a *yaqthin* tree (a type of gourd) to grow beside him. The leaves of the tree protected him and its fruit became his food.
text.147: After the Prophet Jonah's health recovered, Allah sent him back to his people, who at that time numbered over one hundred thousand. They welcomed his arrival well because they were aware that they had previously disappointed him, causing him to leave them. They realized they had obtained Allah's mercy because they had only believed when the signs of Allah's punishment had confronted them. In past communities, faith at such a time was not accepted. Only the people of the Prophet Jonah were exempted from that provision, as stated in Surah Yunus/10:98, which has been explained above. They then lived happily and peacefully until the time appointed for them.

text.149:
Allah asks Prophet Muhammad to question the disbelievers of Mecca about their belief that Allah has a child, and that child is female, even though daughters are considered inferior in their eyes, as Allah says:

"And when one of them is given good tidings of [the birth of] a female, his face becomes darkened, and he suppresses [his rage]." (an-Nahl/16: 58)

What is esteemed in their eyes is a son, because a son is capable of fighting and defending them, as well as glorifying the family name. Therefore, they take sons for themselves while attributing daughters to Allah. Thus, they are basing their belief on a flawed perspective and wanting to have their own way. This division according to their belief becomes unfair, as stated in the following verse:

"Is it for you the males and for Him the females? That is then, an unjust division." (an-Najm/53: 21-22).

Giving daughters, whom they consider inferior, to Allah and sons to themselves, means they are demeaning Allah. The question that Allah asks Prophet Muhammad to pose to the disbelievers of Mecca also implies that their view is wrong. In Allah's view, there is no difference between male and female. What distinguishes people is only their piety (taqwa).
text.150:
The daughters they referred to as daughters of Allah were the angels. Then Allah further strengthened His refutation by questioning whether they witnessed when Allah created or gave birth to the angels as His daughters. They have no evidence whatsoever about that, nor any other evidence, namely revelation. Thus, their view is wrong and constitutes an irresponsible statement because its sin is immense, as stated in the following verse:

And they make the angels, who are servants of the Most Compassionate, females. Did they witness their creation? Their testimony will be recorded, and they will be questioned. (az-Zukhruf/43: 19)
text.151:
Furthermore, Allah more strongly condemns their statement or view that Allah has a child. Allah affirms that their view is merely a fabricated great lie. Because of such fabrication, Allah labels them as great liars. To further emphasize the condemnation of their lie, Allah asks, "Has He chosen daughters over sons?" The meaning is: daughters are low in their view, and sons are noble, so would Allah choose daughters and for them, sons? If that is the case, it means Allah is foolish and they are intelligent. It is this view that Allah condemns, because Allah cannot have offspring and does not need offspring, and should not be insulted with such a view, that for Allah, daughters are sufficient while for them, sons. They must be held accountable for the great sin because of that erroneous view and the sin of those who follow it. Allah says:

"Has then your Lord preferred for you sons, and taken for Himself from among the angels daughters? Verily, you are uttering a grievous saying." (al-Isra'/17: 40)
text.152:

text.154:
The condemnation continues with the question, "What is wrong with you? How can you hold such an opinion?" They are condemned for not having sound minds, because how could Allah, who created everything in the universe, need a child, and that child be female. They are also condemned because, even if they had minds, they were mistaken in their thinking, making their thoughts illogical and unacceptable to reason.

Furthermore, they are condemned for not actually using their minds to analyze the verses of Allah that were conveyed, and not taking them as lessons, even though they are useful. The disbelievers of Mecca already knew about previous communities, but did not take wisdom and lessons from the experiences of those previous communities so that they would believe.
text.155:

They are also rebuked because, even if they had minds, they were mistaken in their thinking, so that the thought was illogical and unacceptable to reason.

The disbelievers of Mecca already knew about previous communities, but did not take wisdom and lessons from the experiences of previous communities so that they would believe.
text.156:
A further refutation presented by Allah to counter the view of the Meccan disbelievers that Allah has offspring, namely angels as His daughters. Allah asks them to present concrete evidence that cannot be refuted, whether that evidence is in physical form or in the form of a statement whose truth is guaranteed. Physical evidence, for example, that Allah gave birth to angels. Non-physical evidence is revelation (wahyu). Of course, they will not be able to present such evidence, because it simply does not exist. Thus, His statement, "Or do you have a clear proof?" is an accurate refutation of their view that Allah has daughters.

Moreover, after that, Allah asks them to present a holy book containing a statement that the angels are His children. They could not possibly obtain such a holy book because Allah never revealed it. In another verse, Allah says something similar to this verse:

"Or have We sent down to them an authority which speaks of what they associate with Him?" (ar-Rum/30: 35)

text.158:
Besides the fact that the disbelievers of Mecca viewed angels as daughters of Allah, they also considered that Allah had a lineage (kinship) relationship with the jinn. Namely, that Allah married a number of female jinn, and from that relationship, angels were born, and those angels were female. This view is very wrong, because if that were the case, the jinn would be equal in status to Allah, even though they themselves acknowledge that they will later be brought before Him, asked to account for their actions, and punished if they are guilty. With that accountability, it means that they are not the same as Allah and are not family of Allah, but are His servants who will be rewarded if they do good and will be punished if they do evil, according to His word:

And they say, "The Most Compassionate has taken a son." Exalted is He. Rather, they (the angels) are honored servants. (al-Anbiya'/21: 26)
text.159:
Furthermore, Allah affirms that He is Exalted above all such assumptions and views, that He has daughters, namely the angels, and that there is a kinship between Him and the jinn. Indeed, He is Exalted above whatever views people have about Him, because His true state cannot be truly depicted by humans, as He cannot be captured by the eye, cannot be heard by the ear, and cannot be etched in the heart. Those who hold such views are polytheists (mushrik).

Allah's chosen servants, those whom He has made to possess the quality of sincerity (ikhlas), will not have wrong views about Him. They always glorify Him to the extent they are able to glorify Him, praise Him to the extent they are able to praise Him, and carry out His commands obediently to the extent they are able to carry them out. Such is also the case with angels in their view. Angels are not daughters of Allah, but are servants of Allah who always devote themselves to Him and carry out His commands without the slightest self-interest.

text.161: In these verses, Allah affirms that the disbelievers of Mecca, along with their objects of worship, namely statues and idols, will not be able to influence and mislead those who believe. This is because the foundation of their belief in deifying those statues is non-existent. Similarly, their claim that angels are the daughters of Allah is baseless. The foundation of faith is revelation, while Allah has never sent down revelation about the correctness of idol worship or about angels being His daughters. Furthermore, those who believe in Allah have a strong faith that will not be influenced by their erroneous beliefs. If anyone is influenced, then they are also candidates for the inhabitants of Hell, namely those who are weak in faith. They will later be cast into Hell (Jahim) together with those who influenced them.
