text.164:
This verse conveys the angels' acknowledgement of themselves, namely that they carry out specific functions and duties. They perform these functions and duties without diminishing or adding anything from what Allah SWT has commanded, as stated in His word:

"Who do not disobey Allah in what He commands them but do what they are commanded." (at-Tahrim/66: 6)
text.165:
Furthermore, the angels explained that in carrying out their duties, they are in rows, meaning they are always ready to carry out their duties and cooperate in strong unity. By being in rows like that, they carry out their duties with enthusiasm, fanfare, and perfection, so that the execution of the task is maximally successful without anything lacking or excessive. This serious execution of duties indicates that they are very obedient to Allah and carry out His commands.

The obedience and seriousness of the angels in carrying out their duties should be emulated by Muslims. In a sahih hadith narrated by Muslim, sourced from Jabir bin Samurah, he said:

From Jabir bin Samurah that the Messenger of Allah once came out to us while we were in the mosque, and he said, 'Why don't you line up as the angels line up in the presence of their Lord?' Then we asked, 'O Messenger of Allah, how do the angels line up in the presence of their Lord?' The Messenger of Allah said, 'They fill up the first row and close ranks.'" (Riwayat Muslim)

Inspired by that verse, Caliph Umar bin Khaththab arranged the rows (saf) before leading the prayer. Reported by Abu Nadhrah:

Umar r.a., when the iqamat was recited, faced the congregation and said, "Arrange your rows, straighten your lines! Allah Ta'ala wants you to follow the behavior of the angels." Then he recited the verse: "wa inna lanahnu ash-shaffun" "O so-and-so, move back, O so-and-so, move forward!" After that, he stepped forward and recited the takbir (to lead the prayer). (Riwayat Ibnu Abi hatim and Ibnu Jarir).
text.166: Then Allah explains the behavior of the angels, that they are always glorifying Him. Tasbih is to sanctify Allah from attributes that are not befitting of Him, whether in the form of deficient attributes, such as weakness, drowsiness, needing helpers/children, and so on, or reprehensible attributes such as being angry, unjust, and so on. Tasbih is not enough with just words, by reciting subhanallah, but it needs to be accompanied by actions. An example of perfect tasbih is what the angels do, where they not only continuously praise Allah but also fully carry out His commands.
text.167: It is explained that the disbelievers of Mecca, before the arrival of the Prophet Muhammad, had actually promised that if they possessed a holy book containing guidance like that possessed by the Jews and Christians, they would believe and carry out the commands written in that holy book with the utmost obedience. They hoped for the coming of a messenger to guide them towards happiness in this world and the hereafter, like that possessed by those two groups. They also wanted to experience the glory that those two groups had once experienced under their respective prophets, because a people under the leadership of a prophet is certainly guaranteed happiness and glory.

text.170:
Allah explains that the messenger they were waiting for has actually come, namely Prophet Muhammad, and the guidance they longed for is already here, namely the Al-Qur'an. However, they deny the prophet and the holy book. Their actions are explained in another verse:

"And they swore by Allah with their strongest oaths that if a warner came to them, they would be more guided than [any of] the [previous] nations. But when a warner came to them, it did not increase them except in aversion." (Fathir/35: 42)

At the end of the verse, Allah SWT affirms that those who disbelieve will later know the consequences of their disbelief. That is, they will suffer both in this world with defeat, and in the hereafter, they will be punished in hell forever. This threat should make them afraid and then believe.
text.171:
Allah affirms that His decree has been in effect from the beginning concerning His messengers. They are defended by Allah, and His believing servants will be victorious. The statement that Allah will help His messengers is affirmed in another verse:

"Indeed, We will support Our messengers and those who believe during the life of this world and on the Day when the witnesses will stand." (al-Mu'min/40: 51)

That the messengers of Allah and the believers will be victorious is also affirmed in another verse:

"Allah has decreed, "I will surely overcome, I and My messengers." Indeed, Allah is Powerful and Exalted in Might." (al-Mujadilah/58: 21)

The proof of Allah's decree is clear from the experiences of previous nations, as their stories have been read in the verses before this, namely that the messengers of Allah and those who believed with them received help from Him, while their disobedient people experienced destruction. Likewise, the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), he and his followers will be helped by Allah as were His other messengers, and he and the Muslims will be victorious over the disbelievers of Mecca, sooner or later.

text.174:
To realize that victory, Allah asked Prophet Muhammad to turn away from them. This means showing a dislike for their rebellious attitude, ignoring their threats, and continuing the da'wah (propagation of Islam) to them with full reliance on Allah, as Allah commanded in another verse:

"And do not obey the disbelievers and the hypocrites but disregard their annoyance, and rely upon Allah. And sufficient is Allah as Disposer of affairs." (al-Ahzab/33: 48)

Besides being commanded to turn away, Prophet Muhammad was also commanded to observe further developments, namely to wait, because Allah's help would surely come. That help was the conquest of Mecca, as stated in the following verse:

"When the victory of Allah has come and the conquest, And you see the people entering into the religion of Allah in multitudes, Then exalt [Him] with praise of your Lord and ask forgiveness of Him. Indeed, He is ever Accepting of repentance." (an-Nashr/110: 1-3)

They will also see developments and wait. But what they are waiting for is only defeat.

text.176:
After the disbelievers were threatened with defeat in this world, so that they would believe, they were threatened with the torment of the Hereafter. Because of their denial or disbelief in the existence of the torment of the Hereafter, they challenged the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) to hasten the occurrence of the torment of the Hereafter while still in this world. To answer this challenge, Allah asks whether they truly want the torment of the Hereafter to be hastened. Allah states that if the torment of the Hereafter were hastened and descended upon their courtyards, the calamity that would befall them would be unimaginable. That is, the calamity would come in the morning, when those who are threatened still want to prolong their sleep before sunrise, so they are not ready to face it.

The severity of a morning calamity can be exemplified by the Prophet's (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) attack on Khaibar at dawn, which resulted in the fall of the fortress:

From Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said, "The Messenger of Allah was in Khaibar in the morning. When they (the Jewish inhabitants of Khaibar) came out with their axes and spears, and saw the army, they fled and shouted, 'Muhammad, by Allah, Muhammad, and his army!' The Prophet said, 'Allah is the Greatest, Khaibar is destroyed. When we reach their courtyards, it will be a very bad morning for those who are threatened.'" (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim).

text.178: Facing the challenge from the disbelievers to hasten the torment of the Hereafter upon them, Allah commands the Prophet to turn away, which is to show a dislike for their rebellious attitude, to ignore their threats, and to continue the da'wah to them with full reliance on Allah, and to observe further developments, which is to wait. For this, patience and reliance (tawakal) are required, just as the attitude in the past when waiting for their destruction in the world. Thus, the torment of the Hereafter is certain to befall them.

For this, patience and reliance are required, just as the attitude in the past when waiting for their destruction in the world. Thus, they will surely receive the torment of the Hereafter.
text.180:
Furthermore, Allah commands Prophet Muhammad saw to glorify Allah, sanctifying Him from all attributes of deficiency and weakness. Allah is the All-Powerful, not weak as the disbelievers perceive, needing a child, a companion, and unable to grant victory to those who believe or inflict punishment immediately. Because He is Most Holy from those attributes of deficiency and weakness, He will surely punish the disbelievers and the wicked and make happy those who believe and do good.

To the messengers and their followers, especially to Prophet Muhammad and the Muslim ummah, Allah gives salvation, which is to ensure that they achieve victory in this world and happiness in the hereafter, namely becoming inhabitants of Paradise.

With the destruction of those who rebel and their punishment in Hell, and the victory of those who believe and their entry as inhabitants of Paradise, it means that Allah is the Most Just and the All-Powerful. He gives good rewards according to good deeds and repays evil deeds according to their evil. Thus, it is proven that He is Praiseworthy and indeed worthy of being praised always.
